body: @navis how did you create so many sinks at the same time without triggering maxPendingPersists to begin throttling ingestion?

@fjy I've used a day log file in local filesystem with hour segment granularity. Any of row count for an hour didn't exceeded `maxRowsInMemory` and persisting didn't happened. Consequently index task throws OOM after passing half of the day(13~14 sinks, I remember).

I know it's not general use cases and we can pass it with lower `maxRowsInMemory` by speculation. But this small patch can lessen the pain.
@fjy can't backport this one, has conflicts in 0.9.0
@fjy there's two commits here, can't cherry-pick easily
Conflicts with 0.9.0 branch. @fjy needs fixes to backport

@drcrallen okay that's not a huge deal

@b-slim can you backport this to 0.9.0?

@du00cs, I see that you've implemented converters to translate from Parquet rather than going with an existing object model. I think it's a lot harder to build and maintain converters rather than using a pre-built object model (like parquet-avro). What was the reason for choosing to build converters?

I'm asking because we've seen others build converters because they didn't know they didn't need to. If that's the case here, you might be able to save a lot of maintenance headache by moving to parquet-avro. If you have questions, feel free to ping me.

@fjy As expected there was not any significant difference between two with varied conditions. But the test result implies that finding first offset for paging can be most time-consuming work for select query.

I've run select query with 100 threshold x 3000 iteration crossing 300K rows in IncrementalIndex. Each number is summation time(msec) of 300 queries. I think we should think of better way for paging than `cursor.advanceTo(offset.startDelta())` (something like `cursor.snapshot()`?).

```
> 431
> 622
> 915
> 1618
> 1838
> 2251
> 2892
> 3956
> 5310
> 6166
>>> 26000
```
:+1: post travis
@himanshug Yes I think it's good to all Avro use cases.
+1  thanks!
Should I resolve this conflict?  Would I open a PR for 0.9.0, cherry-pick the commit from master and resolve the conflicts there - is that the mechanism you guys use?
+1 (backports #2483)

@navis the performance optimization is independent from the API. The point i want to make, is the fact that we have already told druid user that in order to do bound filter the syntax is `x,y,,,z` therefore we can change that and we are suppose to keep it since it is public. Many users of druid have dependency on our public API. IMHO maintaining the API is more important than optimizing code, especially if users are not complaining about it.

And by the way performance of the bound filters depends directly on the performance of `DimensionPredicateFilter` which is used by many other classes. So any optimization i think it should be done there.
@drcrallen i don't see how `LookupCoordinatorManager` is interacting with `LookupReferencesManager` ? i am i missing something ?
@vikramakrishnan do you know of a Curator version that works around this? It looks like the ZK bug is not fixed until 3.5.0, which hasn't been released yet.
@gianm - curator-3.1.0 has a fixed version of zk.
Add the unit test for `getMessage()` on `QueryInterruptedException` and then I'm :+1:
@vikramakrishnan this version of Curator is using ZK 3.5.1-alpha, IMO we would prefer to use released versions.
this exists now, see http://druid.io/docs/0.9.0-rc1/ingestion/data-formats.html
this exists now, see http://druid.io/docs/0.9.0-rc1/ingestion/data-formats.html

We should prevent the transaction failure exception from being written to the logs when it tries to generate a segment ID that has already been issued, since this seems to happen relatively frequently in normal operation and will succeed on the retry. In the logs, you can see it assign segment ID [wikipedia4_2015-08-31T00:00:00.000Z_2015-09-01T00:00:00.000Z_2016-02-18T18:33:03.273Z_2] to sequenceName [index_kafka_wikipedia4_0(2-4)+2(2-4)], then try and fail to issue the same segment ID to sequenceName [index_kafka_wikipedia4_1(2-4)+3(2-4)]. It then retries and succeeds in issuing segment ID [wikipedia4_2015-08-31T00:00:00.000Z_2015-09-01T00:00:00.000Z_2016-02-18T18:33:03.273Z_3] to sequenceName [index_kafka_wikipedia4_1(2-4)+3(2-4)]

The main reason that we have to use `mvn install` to get the tarball is because we've changed the layout of extension files in the tarball, in order to get extensions files we have to call `pull-deps` in the end of the build, which requires extension jars installed in the local repository.

The pain point comes from the fact that releasing RCs becomes very convoluted. In order to get the tarball, you have to manually change pom tags and then do `mvn install`.

A simple hack is let `mvn package` install the jars in the local repository so that we can get the tarball by `mvn package`,

```
diff --git a/pom.xml b/pom.xml
index cacd1aa..2b3273e 100644
--- a/pom.xml
+++ b/pom.xml
@@ -650,6 +650,14 @@
                     <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                     <artifactId>maven-install-plugin</artifactId>
                     <version>2.3.1</version>
+                    <executions>
+                        <execution>
+                            <phase>package</phase>
+                            <goals>
+                                <goal>install</goal>
+                            </goals>
+                        </execution>
+                    </executions>
                 </plugin>
                 <plugin>
                     <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
```

@drcrallen @guobingkun filed #2503 to support QoS on the main port, will remove chatPort from here and also I intend to have tranquility use the main port rather than the chat port.

If I can weigh in a bit here, performance is always paramount and multiple ways to do the same thing is not necessarily a problem as long as there is a "preferred" way and we are just maintaining one of them for legacy reasons.

On the topic of this change in particular.  I like the general idea of it.  It seems to be trying to simplify the various logic and making it easier to actually do the queries.  I think a lot of it is likely working around the annoyance of how difficult it is to actually register new filter objects.

It can make it a little more difficult if we implement `!=` and other things this way to do optimizations.  Should we expect the "not" filter or should we expect a selector with a `!=`.

If I can redirect the effort a little bit, I think this might be really nice if accompanied by a "new" filter that essentially implements a "WHERE" clause.  There could be a part of the query pipeline added that essentially rewrites the "WHERE" clause into a set of the "primitive" filters that we have today.  If we had that, then we could hide the "selector" filter behind said rewriting.  We could tell users to use that method for their filters and behind the scenes, we can generate whatever ends up being the most performant.

How does that sound?

@fjy the PRs I've been putting in about HadoopTask's classloader don't change the behavior of the job once it is running in hadoop. It only changes the behavior on the peon before the task gets registered with hadoop. @navis please Let me explain more what's my point:
1 - This PR is introducing operators like `<`or`>` and doesn't cover all the aspect of it and bound filter does so i don't see how we can have two filters together.
2 -  While it is true from a human perspective it is cool to have one filter that does everything using math like operators, but i think druid API is designed to be automatically generated. So having Filters in the form of POJOs structure is better IMO than having a filter that uses special characters like `!=`. 
 3 - IMO i don't think it is the way to go to have multiple API doing the same thing, if there is no reason to change the API i don't see why we changed.

So know you may ignore 2 and 3, but i don't think 1 can be ignored. If so please explain how this can be ignored or fixed.
Thanks!

ok, looks like the TPTR adds work items to a ConcurrentSkipListSet and needs them to be comparable. I think it doesn't make sense to define the actual class as Comparable and having non-reference "equals"/"hashCode", since the reference-based "equals"/"hashCode" actually works well for other usages in other task runners.

So I will add a Comparator to the TPTR specifically.
